snippet: Villagers in Diyala Province saw much death during the worst of Iraq’s carnage over the past decade, but they say what is happening now is far worse.
abstract: Villagers in Iraq's Diyala Province say current violence in region is far worse than any of Iraq’s carnage over past decade; Iraqi leaders worry that violence may be sign of what awaits rest of country if government cannot quell growing mayhem that many people trace to civil war in Syria, which has inflamed sectarian divisions.

byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi contributed reporting from Muqdadiya and Baghdad, Duraid Adnan from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Diyala Province, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: Villagers in Diyala Province saw much death during the worst of Iraq’s carnage over the past decade, but they say what is happening now is far worse.

headline.main: Sectarian Violence Reignites in an Iraqi Town
headline.print_headline: Sectarian Violence Reignites in an Iraqi Town
